Introduction

Penile fracture is a relatively uncommon but serious urological emergency characterized by traumatic rupture of the tunica albuginea that surrounds the corpus cavernosum (

figure 1
).  It typically occurs from blunt force to an erect penis, most often during vigorous sexual intercourse.  Symptoms include sudden loss of erection, severe penile pain, and edema and ecchymosis of the penis.  Prompt surgical intervention to repair the tunica albuginea is necessary to avoid complications such as erectile dysfunction.

Pathophysiology



Penile fracture typically occurs during sexual intercourse when the penis slips out of the vagina and is accidentally and forcefully thrust against the perineum or pelvic bone.  The excessive bending force tears the tunica albuginea, which is the thick, fibrous sheath that envelops the blood-filled corpus cavernosum.  Sheath rupture leads to immediate detumescence (loss of erection) and hematoma formation within the penis.  Concomitant urethral injury may also occur due to the close proximity of the urethra to the corpus spongiosum.

Risk factors



  • Vigorous sexual activity
  • Alcohol or drug use during sex (can impair judgment and coordination, leading to accidental trauma)
  • Penile anatomical deformity, such as from Peyronie disease (fibrous scar tissue in the penis), which can predispose the penis to fractures

Clinical presentation



  • Sudden onset of severe penile pain
  • Immediate loss of erection
  • Audible sound (some patients report hearing a snap or pop at time of injury)
  • Rapid onset of penile swelling and ecchymosis
  • Visible penile deformity (eg, angulation)

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of penile fracture is primarily clinical, based on the sudden onset of penile pain, detumescence, swelling, and bruising following genital trauma during erection.  Ultrasonography or MRI may be used to confirm the diagnosis in equivocal cases, but patients with clear signs of penile fracture should undergo immediate operative exploration and repair.



Concomitant urethral injury occurs in approximately 20% of penile fracture cases.  The following findings suggest urethral tear/rupture and warrant further evaluation with a retrograde urethrogram:



  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • Hematuria
  • Dysuria
  • Urinary retention


A retrograde urethrogram is performed by instilling contrast dye into the urethra (through the meatus) while x-rays are taken (

image 1
).  Extravasation of the dye beyond the urethral border indicates a defect that should be repaired during surgery.

Differential diagnosis



  • Superficial dorsal vein rupture:  is an extremely rare condition characterized by traumatic rupture of the dorsal penile vein (rather than the tunica albuginea).  Ecchymosis can be quite significant, but, unlike in penile fracture, there is typically no sudden popping sound, significant pain, or rapid detumescence.
  • Penile contusion:  can result from minor trauma to the penis and involves hematoma formation without tunica albuginea rupture.  Penile contusions typically occur in a detumescent penis from direct trauma such as a straddle injury.

Management



Definitive management of penile fracture involves urgent surgical repair of the tunica albuginea.  Patients require regular postoperative follow-up visits to monitor for proper recovery.  Patients are advised to refrain from sexual activity for 4-6 weeks following surgery to allow for adequate healing.

Prognosis



With prompt diagnosis and intervention, the prognosis for penile fracture is generally favorable.  Early operative repair is extremely important to prevent complications including erectile dysfunction, persistent hematoma, and abnormal penile curvature.

Summary



Penile fracture is a rare urological emergency that occurs when a blunt force is exerted on an erect penis, causing rupture of the tunica albuginea.  This results in the rapid onset of penile pain, edema, and ecchymosis, and an immediate loss of erection.  Penile fracture requires prompt diagnosis and urgent surgical intervention to prevent future sexual dysfunction.
